metadata.case_name: University of Cochin v. Dr. N. Raman Nair

facts.text: Dr. N. Raman Nair applied on 15-10-1972 for the post of Reader in the Department of Hindi and stood 1st in the order of merit as determined by the Board of Appointments.
Cochin University Act 30 of 1971 came into force, published on 13-8-1971.

Syndicate of University passed resolution on 17-7-1972 stating that rules under Section 6(2) be implemented for teaching staff except Professor posts, which shall be filled exclusively on merit, with reservation quota provided additionally in Readers, Lecturers, etc. collectively.
Syndicate passed resolution on 6-1-1973 appointing Dr. A. Ramchandra Dey to the post of Reader in Hindi.

Kerala High Court in O.P. No. 102 of 1973 dated 29-11-1973 quashed Syndicate resolutions of 17-7-1972 and 6-1-1973, directed University to make appointments in conformity with Section 6(2) of the Act.
Vacancy for Reader in Hindi occurred on 10-7-1971, listed as first vacancy in Ex. P.3 prepared by Standing Committee on 1-1-1973.
Standing Committee list (Ex. P.3) on 1-1-1973 detailed vacancies, dates, allocations: e.g., Lecturer SMS 10-7-1971 Open Mrs. Armies George; Reader in Hindi 10-7-1971 Res. O.B.C.
Rotation rules commence from 15-6-1967 per Rule 15 note, but for University from Act's enforcement.
Dr. Nair and Dr. Ramchandra Dev both now holding posts of Readers in Hindi as University needs expanded.

legal_issues.text: Whether the Syndicate's resolution of 17-7-1972 implementing Section 6(2) of Cochin University Act by excluding Professor posts and applying reservations collectively to other teaching posts is valid.

Scope of University's power to apply Kerala State and Subordinate Service Rules 14-17 mutatis mutandis under Section 6(2), including classification of services/classes/categories and application of rotation to vacancies in order of occurrence.
Whether the post of Reader in Hindi is a separate category entitling the top merit candidate to appointment as first vacancy under open competition in rotation.
Whether rotation applies to vacancies in order of occurrence, starting post-Act enforcement.

petitioner_arguments.text: University followed rotation by treating teaching staff (Readers, Lecturers etc.) collectively except Professors on merit; power to apply rules mutatis mutandis allows adaptation to situations, including altering for University needs.
Resolution of 17-7-1972 merely categorises posts reasonably for collective application; rotation alternately open and reserved.

respondent_arguments.text: Post of Reader in Hindi is a particular category; first post reserved for open competition on merits under Rule 14(c); stood 1st in merit, entitled to it.
University wrongly interpreted reservation rules as applying collectively not separately; vacancy first in order, allocated wrongly to reserved.

court_reasoning.text: Section 6(1) eliminates unjustifiable discrimination against individuals; Section 6(2) ensures equality between groups, enabling backward classes appointments via Rules 14-17 mutatis mutandis.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Modifies individual merit for group equality.

court_reasoning.text: University must classify services/classes/categories reasonably; cannot exempt Professors entirely; may treat teaching posts collectively or separately.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Classification prima facie reasonable unless assailed.

court_reasoning.text: Rotation applies to vacancies in order of occurrence, not advertisement; starts post-Act for University from 13-8-1971.
Mutatis mutandis allows formal adaptations, not substantive changes like excluding Professors or altering rotation.
court_reasoning.key_observation: High Court right; cannot amend rules.

court_reasoning.text: Resolution 17-7-1972 invalid: excludes Professors, ambiguous, inseparable parts attempt to alter rules.
Reader Hindi vacancy first (10-7-1971), should be open if first in rotation post-Act.
court_reasoning.key_observation: But remit to University for classification.

holdings.text: University has power to reasonably classify posts/services for applying rotation rules under Section 6(2).
Syndicate resolution 17-7-1972 wholly invalid for excluding Professors and attempting to alter rotation.
Rotation applies to vacancies in chronological order post-Act enforcement; mutatis mutandis does not permit substantive changes.
University to pass fresh resolution for reasonable classification and apply rules to determine appointments.

statutes_cited.name: Cochin University Act, 1971
statutes_cited.relevance: Mandates no discrimination; requires application of Rules 14(a),(b),(c),15,16,17 mutatis mutandis for appointments.

statutes_cited.name: Kerala State and Subordinate Service Rules
statutes_cited.relevance: Reservation and rotation: 20-unit block (10 open, 8 OBC, 2 SC/ST); sub-rotations; passing over if no candidate.

outcome.summary: Appeal dismissed subject to elucidation of High Court directions; University to make reasonable classification of posts and pass fresh resolution in accordance with law to apply Section 6(2) and rules for appointments.
outcome.relief_granted: Directions to University for fresh classification and appointments; no specific relief to parties as both now appointed.

key_quotes.text: "Section 6(2) is meant to ensure equality of treatment between citizens as members of groups, and, in particular, to enable backward classes to secure appointments so as to remove the gap between the advanced and the backward."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Explains purpose of reservation under Section 6(2).

key_quotes.text: "The power to apply the rules mutatis-mutandis does not include the power of amending the substantial provision in the rules."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "We consider the resolution to be wholly invalid."
key_quotes.speaker: court
